awd_titl_txt: The Kinetics and Mechanism of the Halogen Initiated Oxidation of Gas Phase Elemental Mercury and its Role in Atmospheric and Combustion Chemistry.
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Anthony Hynes of the University of Miami is being funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Division of Chemistry to study the chemical processes that oxidize gas phase mercury atoms. Their typical background concentrations in the atmosphere are very low and they pose no threat to human health. However, if the mercury atoms are oxidized, they form mercuric compounds that are much more soluble and much more rapidly incorporated into terrestrial ecosystems. The mechanisms of the atmospheric cycling of mercury are one of the most poorly understood components of atmospheric chemistry. The chemical mechanisms responsible for oxidation of elemental mercury and even the actual identity of the compounds that make up oxidized mercury are not well known. This research provides information needed to better model the chemistry of atmospheric mercury and use the model to develop sound emission control strategies. In addition to engaging graduate students in research, the PI participates in educational outreach programs at his university which are aimed at low-income first-generation college-bound students.

	The project involves a series of measurements of the rate coefficients, and, where possible, the mechanisms of the halogen-initiated oxidation of gas phase elemental mercury. The mercurous halides that initially form, HgCl and HgBr, are weakly bound and the hence the rates of further reactions to form stable mercuric compounds are critical. The reactions of the mercurous halides with halogen atoms and NO2 to produce stable mercuric compounds have been proposed as potential routes to oxidized mercury formation in the atmosphere. Professor Hynes and his students measure the rate coefficients for these reactions and determine the relative importance of oxidation and reduction channels. The experimental approach utilizes the Pulsed Laser Photolysis-Pulsed Laser Induced Fluorescence (PLP-PLIF) technique. This technique allows the rates and mechanisms of the reactions to be measured over the range of tropospheric temperatures and pressures, allowing them to be used in models without the need for extrapolation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A detailed understanding of the biogeochemical cycling of mercury and the routes to the production of organomercury compounds in ecosystems is a critical issue from a human health perspective. Direct exposure to mercury is primarily through the ingestion of methylmercury from fish consumption. Wet or dry deposition of oxidized mercury is an important step in a complex process that involves both chemistry and microbiology and eventually produces alkyl mercuric compounds.  Hence, an understanding of the overall budget and mechanism of chemical transformation of mercury in both its elemental and combined forms is critically important The societal impact of mercury pollution is considerable. This includes lowered IQ in children whose mothers are exposed to elevated levels of mercury when pregnant. A 2011 report by the Arctic Monitoring and Assessment Programmed (AMAP) reported that mercury levels are continuing to rise in some Arctic species, despite reductions over the past 30 years in emissions from human activities. A recent study of the preschool children in three regions of the Arctic showed that almost 59% of children exceeded the provisional tolerable weekly intake (PTWI) level of mercury for children. Control of mercury emissions has been an issue at both the national and international level. Reductions in mercury emissions have been the focus of global negotiations that have led to the Minimata Convention on Mercury.

In the atmosphere mercury exists primary as gas phase elemental mercury, Hg(0). To be efficiently deposited and incorporated into the terrestrial ecosystem Hg(0) must undergo atmospheric oxidation to stable mercuric compounds and multiple models have been developed to predict atmospheric mercury cycling. However, the chemical reactions in these models are based on computational chemistry and there is very little experimental data to support the calculated rates and reaction mechanisms.

 It is now clear that gas phase chemical reactions produce rapid atmospheric transformation of mercury. Bromine: mercury interactions are thought to be the dominant oxidation process in the troposphere. Recent work has proposed that reactions of HgBr with NO2 and O3 are important reactions in oxidizing the mercurous compound into a stable mercuric compound and single studies of each reaction have been reported in the literature. In this work we report results on our studies of each reaction. For the reaction of  HgBr with NO2 we find that the reaction proceeds via a pressure dependent three body recombination. Our results give rate coefficients that are a factor of two faster than the one published study (R. Wu et al , Chem. Phys. Lett., 2020,  759 , 137928). In addition, we find no evidence for the reaction proceeding via a reduction channel that regenerates Hg(0).

The published study of the HgBr + O3 reaction was conducted at low pressures of N2 under conditions that resulted in complications from secondary chemistry dominating the experimental profiles of HgBr (J.C. Gómez; Martín et al. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys., 2022,24, 12419-12432).     In this work we report a study of this reaction in high pressures of O2 that allow us to eliminate complications from secondary chemistry and obtain readily interpretable pseudo-first order decays of HgBr. The photolysis wavelength that has been used to photolyze the HgBr precursor, HgBr2, overlaps the peak of the O3 absorption spectrum and a significant fraction of the O3  is photolyzed eventually producing an extremely high concentration of O3P which reacts rapidly with HgBr giving HgBrO which also reacts rapidly with O atoms and this secondary chemistry dominates the temporal profiles of HgBr requiring a complex analysis to extract rate coefficients.

 Our experiments were carried  out in N2 / O2 mixtures at pressures between 750-455 Torr with O2 pressures that varied between 430 and 270 Torr. The critical factor in working under these conditions is that the three body recombination of O with O2, to regenerate O3 proceeds much more rapidly than any other reaction.

Under our conditions the recombination to form O3 has proceeded to completion in ~30 ms and all HgBr decays follow good pseudo first order behavior.  We measure a rate coefficient of (6.6 ± 0.7) x 10-11 cm3 molecule-1 s-1. The Gomez Martin et al. study reports a value of (7.5 ± 0.6) x 10-11 cm3 molecule-1 s-1 and the agreement between the two studies, giving rate coefficients that overlap within the quoted uncertainties, is remarkable given the very different sets of experimental conditions in the two studies. Our work supports the conclusion of Gomez Martin et al. that this reaction is the dominant sink of HgBr in the troposphere. Overall this work greatly increases are confidence in the rate coefficients for these two reactions and shows the potential for conducting experimental determinations of the rates and mechanisms of the critical reactions in atmospheric mercury cycling.
